div.head: Overview

item.p: a supernormal generalized power of retention and memory developed mainly by bodhisattvas at certain stages of the path and seen as an important means of further progress;
one or many particular, named instructions or powers that allow access to certain realizations;
a set of syllables or words that similarly hold and transmit an instruction, but principally to confer protection;

an actual text (or the category of texts) centered on a dhÄraá¹‡Ä«â€”in any of the above sensesâ€”that typically also contains additional material such as an introductory narrative, instructions for its use, and details of its benefits.

div.p: The notion of dhÄraá¹‡Ä« as an essential element of the path is widespread in Buddhist traditions, and dhÄraá¹‡Ä« textsâ€”especially protective onesâ€”have played an important part in Buddhist practice and popular belief. particularly in the MahÄyÄna. It is by no means confined to tantric traditions, despite certain parallels with tantric uses of mantra.

The Kangyur contains a large number of dhÄraá¹‡Ä« texts, some classified as sÅ«tra but many placed in the category of Action (kriyÄ) Tantra, even though some of these are not obviously tantric in nature. div.head: Etymology and Usage
div.p: The Buddhist spiritual path is an explicitly long-term undertaking, and for a teaching to be put into practice and subsequently made available to others, clear and accurate memory, retention over long periods, and verifiable transmission are all of obvious importance.

The Sanskrit term dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is derived from the Sanskrit root âˆšdhá¹› (â€œto holdâ€ or â€œto maintainâ€), and among its wide range of meanings most are closely related to the retainingâ€”in the mind or awareness, in the memory, in spoken words, or in writingâ€”of a particular teaching, realization, or approach to awakening. The â€œholdingâ€ of dhÄraá¹‡Ä« in most senses seems to refer more to what it is that holds than to what is held, although the distinction is not always a clear one.

Although dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is sometimes compared to forms of mnemonic technique, the way a dhÄraá¹‡Ä« holds (or provides access to) content beyond itself seems to rely not so much on arbitrary associations functioning as cues as on the kind of relationships that link a general or abstract principle to its specific or actual applications.

Perhaps because the notion of dhÄraá¹‡Ä« was widely accepted and understood, a fully informative, systematic explanation of exactly what dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is does not seem to be found in the sÅ«tras themselves. Passages about dhÄraá¹‡Ä« within the sÅ«tras nevertheless yield helpful information, and the material they contain can be classified according to the principal sense of the term that, among the range of such senses, is the most relevant in each case. Further perspectives can be found in explanations in the treatises; these remain to be fully explored. In the following breakdown of some of the senses that can be distinguished from the texts, it should be emphasized that there is a great deal of overlap. While usage and aspect vary, the underlying meaning remains constant.

q.p: Regarding this [topic), what are the bodhisattvas' forms of [mental] retention?'119 In brief, they should be regarded as being of four types: (1) retention of the Dharma, (2) retention of meaning, (3) retention by means of spells, and (4) the retention that is directed toward attainment of a bodhisattva's forbearance. Regarding this [topic), what is retention of the Dharma? Here a bodhisattva attains a development of power"20 consisting of wisdom and recollection such that by means of it he or she can retain [in the mind] for an immeasurable period of time immeasurable numbers of scriptures containing collections of words, assertions, and syllables that were not committed to memory and were not recited aloud, in the order that they were created and in the order that they were arranged, merely by having listened to them. Regarding this [topic), what is retention of meaning? The description] is the same as before, but in this case there is this differ-ence. [A bodhisattva] retains [in the mind] for an immeasurable period of time immeasurable numbers of meanings relating to the very same Dharma teachings [contained in those scriptures, without having committed them to memory and without having reviewed them in the mind. Regarding this topic, what is retention by means of spells? Here a bodhisattva attains a power of one-pointed concentration such that by means of it those mantra spells that [have the potential to] spiritually influence beings and cure their infectious diseases are rendered effective, supremely effective, and unfailing [in their ability] to cure many different kinds of infectious diseases. This [quality] is called a bodhisattva's "reten-tion by means of spells." Regarding this topic, what is a bodhisattva's [form of mental] retention that is directed toward attainment of a bodhisattva's forbearance? 6. They do not contain any meaning. Their meaning is that they have no meaning." Following that, he or she does not seek any further meaning. In this way, he or she gains a correct realization of the meanings of these mantra spells. 7. Having gained a correct realization of the meanings of these mantra spells, he or she then gains a correct realization of the meanings of all entities that conforms with that very understanding of the mantra spells]. Without having heard (the meaning of all entities] from anyone else, he or she realizes it in the following manner: "No meaning that pertains to a [real] essence can be established by means of any expressions in relation to any entity. 8. This ineffable essential nature is the meaning that represents their essential nature." After he or she has correctly realized the meaning that represents the essential nature of all entities in this way, [a bodhisattva] does not seek any other meaning. Through having gained a realization of that meaning, he or she attains a joyful rapture. What a bodhisattva attains on the strength of these mantra spells is called a "forbearance." This should be understood as the [form of mental] retention that is directed toward the attainment of a bodhisattva's forbearance. Regarding this (topic], after having gone beyond the first span of time that is made up of countless kalpas," a bodhisattva who has entered the stage of a pure superior attitude"7 attains forms of the retention of the Dharma and the retention of meanings that are sure, firm, and exalted. (r) He or she does not have attachment for sensory pleasures. (2) He or she does nor develop envy toward those who have attained an elevated status and he or she remains free of envy.
